displayed_text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - um that the side effects from the hormone therapies were getting a little bit too much for you. Patient: Yes. Doctor: And your preference, which I agreed with at the time, was to stop the Lupron you get. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And given that your PSA level is very low, it was an investment point level, that you basically stop that, allow the testosterone to recover if you did good by itself, and then to monitor the PSA to see where that was at. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So on the one hand, it does move over time, if the testosterone continues to increase, which it probably will, may feed the cancer. But on the other hand, in the meantime, your quality of life should be better than it would have been with a testosterone let’s say less than twenty. Patient: Okay. That’s’ Doctor: So it’s kind of the choice that we made, and this is sort of the natural expectation of what we were expecting to see. Patient: You would recommend having it done Doc? Doctor: No. There’s no evidence that people like you that people like you in controlling cancer. Patient: You know I was reading an article a while back that I like about it’s going to become common for folks to live into their hundreds.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So how are things going since the last time I saw you a couple months ago? Patient: I’m feelin’ fine. Well, let’s put it this way… Energy, lack of energy. That’s my number one complaint. Doctor: Okay. Is that getting any better, any worse or staying the same? Patient: I - It appears to be getting worse. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I don’t know, I…maybe it’s age. Doctor: You’re not that old yet. (laughs) Patient: Oh. (chuckles) Doctor: That’s young, in this day and age. Patient: Yeah. Uh-huh. Doctor: Any other new symptoms? So fatigue is maybe a bit worse? Patient: I feel so; I, I uh I govern that by my ability to you know do things around the house. So whether it’s supporting activities, playing golf I don’t have any energy. And possibly because I’m a little heavier now, too. I’ve gained a few pounds.

Family Member: it would not be a good idea. His doctor took him off. His primary care doctor Doctor: Mm Hmm. Family Member: before all this treatment even started. Doctor: Really? Family Member: She was like… Doctor: Well now that his kidney function is improving, we may be able to restart it if your sugars keep on being high. Okay so next time what I’m gonna suggest is that we get fasting bloodwork Family Member: Okay. Doctor: and see where things are at. Okay? That way I’ll be able to see if we need to put you back on the medication. Family Member: I think that’s a good idea. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: But that’s not a crutch either to say I’m back on Metformin I can eat cookies. Patient: Oh, oh…

Patient: Well I got a… Doctor: But you don’t want to. Patient: I got to address that. I got to address that and… Doctor: All the more reason to do surgery if it holds up your paddleball and all that stuff right? Patient: Well maybe, yeah, right. Family Member: Well what the – will that lesions – his legs are really weak and they hurt. Would that lesion? Patient: It’s not bad is it? Doctor: I mean I don’t think it’s worse, but it’s not getting better. Family Member: So would that lesion affect his legs also, is it the same stem you know nerve system? Doctor: You know usually not. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Because I mean hopefully – the arm nerves are on the outside. Family Member: Okay.

Patient: Is this something that’s possible. Doctor: When we do a scan it only tells us after you have X amount of tumors or cells that have glommed together how big it is. Patient: Mhmm, mhmm. Yep. Doctor: Right? So I can only report out what I see, but if I were to open you up || like that… Patient: Yep. Doctor: …it would show more… Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …and it would show probably very small areas. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Um and those are non-targetable. Patient: Right. Doctor: So that’s just the – the struggle is unless that thing whichever one decides to block anything off… Patient: Mhmm.

Family Member: Yeah. Now will that show if there was any problem or would it? Doctor: Well – Family Member: I know MRI show more. Doctor: Well they both can show that. I think it’s more of what are we looking for to do with that. Family Member: Um, hum. Doctor: He’s sort of past that. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: It’s not a great utility for us at this moment. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But sometimes if we find that it’s useful later we certainly can. Yeah. Family Member: Now do you think after three months, after he’s on medication, what scans will you be taking? Will you be taking like the - Doctor: The CAT scan.

Patient: - you understand is riding that motorcycle. Doctor: Okay. Patient: That’s it. Doctor: You’re just gonna have to be careful. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I know it’s a joy for you. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You just can’t overdo it or you’re gonna be in the hospital between here and F___. You just got to be careful. Even if you end up in the hospital you just call me and I’ll work with your docs. It will be fine. Okay. So just get rest on the road. Patient: Oh yeah, oh yeah. Doctor: Okay. Alright. Patient: I mean you know I ain’t stupid. Doctor: Hi. Healthcare Professional: Hi.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You know then clearly me telling you you know what things are getting worse just come off this and go get… Patient: Yeah, that’s right. Doctor: Because that would be a really bad outcome overall. Patient: Yeah but it’s not like that so that’s… Doctor: Yeah, that’s a good thing. That’s why we’re having this back and forth even. Patient: Yes. Doctor: If it was clear cut growth I’m not gonna keep you on something that’s not helping you. Patient: Right. Doctor: You know I would tell you ditch this and just go get some other treatment. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: So for now we gave you the pills for today. Patient: Right.

Patient: Good. Family Member: We like him very much. (Chuckles) Doctor: Okay, anything else? Patient: That’s it. Family Member: That’s it. Doctor: Let me see what we have in here in terms of just follow-up. So he’s already set up for his shot. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So January thirtieth. Family Member: Okay, right. Doctor: So everything else that we’re going to add up now will be related to the study. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Everybody gets card, okay. Now is that here? Doctor: Yeah. So, there is a Dr. M____. We’re gonna write this down for you guys Patient: Okay. Alright. Doctor: and then we’ll make the referral but just so you know we’ll start the prior authorization process so by the time you see him we’ve got everything under way and then he’ll just take over. Patient: Okay and then I see you after or during? Doctor: Right, so like I’m kind of just hovering because we’re trying not to add more work. Patient: Okay. Doctor: He tells me every time you see him once a month because he draws blood work and everything so then I know you pop up in my systems like oh, you’re in the systems. So, if there’s issues though like things that aren’t going right and you feel whatever, you tell him but then you could always come back to see me anytime. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I’m just gonna put, I’m trying to think, am I giving you the shot or is that your neurologist? Who’s giving you the Lupron? Patient: You are. Doctor: So, you’d have to come back anyways. Did you get a shot today or are you coming?
